title: Thursday Morning Business Brief
text:
Thursday Morning Business Brief October 1, 2015, 6:02 AM 
World stocks are up Thursday after a Chinese manufacturing index improved and buying appetite strengthened after substantial falls in stock prices in the past quarter. Germany's DAX rose 0.9 percent to 9,747.25 and France's CAC 40 gained 1.4 percent to 4,516.12. Britain's FTSE 100 climbed 1.3 percent to 6,136.84. Futures pointed to more gains on Wall Street after yesterday's rebound. Dow futures added 0.8 percent to 16,294 and S&P 500 futures rose 0.7 percent to 1,922.80. WASHINGTON (AP) - Four reports due out today will give a snapshot of the economy. The Labor Department reports on the number of people who applied for benefits last week, while the Commerce Department reports on construction spending in August. A trade group of purchasing managers issues its index of manufacturing activity for September, and Freddie Mac reports on average U.S. mortgage rates. PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - Recreational marijuana use is legal in Oregon. The states marijuana shops began selling to anyone at least 21 years of age. Oregon becomes the third state to sell marijuana for recreational use, following Washington and Colorado. Alaska could begin retail sales next year. GAINESVILLE, Fla. (AP) - One of the world's largest fertilizer makers is settling a massive hazardous waste lawsuit for nearly $2 billion. The Justice Department says the settlement will help clean up pollution and upgrade leaky facilities in Florida and Louisiana. The department and the Environmental Protection Agency are to announce the agreement with Minnesota-based The Mosaic Co. today. The court still needs to sign off on the deal. UNDATED (AP) - Microsoft is inviting NFL fans to share ideas on how to use technology to make the NFL game more efficient, more competitive and more entertaining. It's part of the "Imagine Bowl" and fans will have until Dec. 1 to submit their concepts online. The grand prize winner will receive a trip to Super Bowl 50 and $50,000. Â© 2015 Associated Press.
